bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Fred L. Soper, March 13, 1953

div1.p: Hench agrees with Soper that it would be beneficial to re-publish some of the most important yellow fever articles by Finlay, Reed, et al. He inquires about English translations of Finlay's articles.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Fred L. Soper, March 13, 1953
div1.opener:
March 13, 1953
Dr. Fred L. Soper, Director
Pan American Sanitary Bureau
World Health Organization
Washington, D. C.
My dear Doctor Soper:
div1.p:
I was indeed sorry that you could not attend the dedication of Camp Lazear
in Cuba.

I too wish that there could be a republication of some of the most important
yellow fever articles of Finlay, Reed and his associates. I have tried
to find in Cuba or in Washington translations of Finlay's papers. I have
a copy of his Selected Works but as you know, many of his papers are given
there only in Spanish. Do you know of any complete collection of his
articles in English? I would certainly like to find one. If Reed's papers
are republished, may I take the liberty of saying that they need some editing
as there are quite a few minor errors and contradictions in the first five
or six papers of Reed and his associates, nothing important but obviously
Reed, as we know, wrote one or two of these papers under great pressure, writing
part of them in his quarters at the Post Hospital, Columbia Barracks, and
part of them probably enroute to the meetings and part in Washington. Doctor
Ames had part of the important notes; therefore there are many minor contra-
dictions regarding the dates when the yellow fever volunteers developed
their illness and so on.
I am sending you a copy of the memorandum of my December visit.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
